question: All right - if we take off through that bayou-
answer: Wait a minute! Who elected you leader a this outfit?

question: Well, Pete, I just figured it should be the one with capacity for abstract thought. But if that ain't the consensus view, hell, let's put her to a vote!
answer: Suits me! I'm votin' for yours truly!

question: How ya been, Wash? Been what, twelve, thirteen year'n?
answer: You've grown chatty. I expect you'll want them chains knocked off. They foreclosed on Cousin Vester. He hanged himself a year come May.

question: And Uncle Ratliff?
answer: The anthrax took most of his cows. The rest don't milk, and he lost a boy to mumps.

question: Where's Cora, Cousin Wash?
answer: Couldn't say. Mrs. Hogwallop up and

question: Oh no! Lord have mercy!
answer: What do we do now, Everett?

question: Fire! I hate fire! NOW HOLD ON, BOYS-AINTCHA EVER HEARD OF A NEGOTIATION? MAYBE WE CAN TALK THIS THING OUT!
answer: Yeah, let's negotiate 'em, Everett.

question: Now hold on, Pete, we gotta speak with one voice here - CAREFUL WITH THAT FIRE NOW, BOYS!
answer: You should be in bed, little fella.

question: Well, you're right there, but the ol' tactician's already got a plan- -for the transportation, that is; I don't know how I'm gonna keep my coiffure in order.
answer: How's this a plan? How're we gonna get a car?

question: Sell that. I figured it could only have painful associations for Wash.
answer: To Washington Bartholomew Hogwallop. From his loving Cora. Ay-More Fie- dellis.

question: You mis'able little sneak thief... You stole from my kin!
answer: Who was fixing to betray us!

question: You didn't know that at the time!
answer: So I borrowed it till I did know!

question: That don't make no sense!
answer: Pete, it's a fool looks for logic in the chambers of the human heart. What the hell's that singing?

question: Pete, don't be ignorant-
answer: Well that's it boys, I been redeemed! The preacher warshed away all my sins and transgressions. It's the straight-and-narrow from here on out and heaven everlasting's my reward!

question: Delmar what the hell are you talking about? - We got bigger fish to fry-
answer: Preacher said my sins are warshed away, including that Piggly Wiggly I knocked over in Yazoo!

question: I thought you said you were innocent a those charges.
answer: Well I was lyin' - and I'm proud to say that that sin's been warshed away too! Neither God nor man's got nothin' on me now! Come on in, boys, the water's fine!

question: How much does he pay? All right boys, just follow my lead. Who's the honcho around here?
answer: I am. Hur you?

question: Well sir, my name is Jordan Rivers and these here are the Soggy Bottom Boys outta Cottonelia Mississippi- Songs of Salvation to Salve the Soul. We hear you pay good money to sing into a can.
answer: Well that all depends. You boys do Negro songs?

question: Sir, we are Negroes. All except our a-cump- uh, company-accompluh- uh, the fella that plays the gui-tar.
answer: Well, I don't record Negro songs. I'm lookin' for some ol'-timey material. Why, people just can't get enough of it since we started broadcastin' the 'Pappy O'Daniel Flour Hour', so thanks for stoppin' by, but-

question: Million point two.
answer: Five... hunnert... thousand... each.

question: Four hundred, Delmar.
answer: Izzat right?

question: Uh... Itta Bena...
answer: Itta Bena, now, uh, that would be...

question: Isn't it, uh...
answer: I'm thinkin' it's uh, you could take this road to, uh...

question: ...Nah, that ain't right... I'm thinkin' of...
answer: ...I believe, unless I'm very much mistaken - see, we've been away for several years, uh...

question: Hop on in while you give it a think. Any a you boys know your way around a Walther PPK?
answer: Well now, that's where we cain't help ya. I don't believe it's in Mississippi. Friend, some of your folding money has come unstowed.

question: Just stuff it down that sack there. You boys aren't badmen, I take it?
answer: Well, funny you should ask-I was bad, till yesterday, but me'n Pete here been saved. My name's Delmar, and that there's Everett.

question: Grab the tiller, will ya buddy? Hand up that Thompson, Jack.
answer: Say, what line of work are you in, George?

question: COME AND GET ME, COPPERS! YOU ...cows... I hate cows worse than coppers!
answer: Aww, George, not the livestock.

question: HA-HA! COME ON YOU MISERABLE SALARIED SONSABITCHES! COME AND GET ME! COME ON BOYS! WE'RE GOIN' FOR THE RECORD-THREE BANKS IN TWO HOURS! OKAY FOLKS! HOLD THE APPLAUSE AND
answer: He's a live wire though, ain't he?

question: Damn but that was some fun though, won it George?!
answer: ...yeah...

question: Almost makes me wish I hadn't been saved! Jackin' up banks - I can see how a fella could derive a lot a pleasure and satisfaction out of it!
answer: ...it's okay...

question: Whoa doggies!
answer: ...Well, I'm takin' off. You boys can have the automobile. 'N might as well take my share a the riches.

question: What the - where you goin', George?
answer: ...I dunno... who cares...

question: ...Shutup, Delmar. PULL OVER!
answer: I guess o' Pete's got the itch.

question: Howdy do, ladies. Name of Pete! Maybe I could help you with the, uh- Ahem. I, uh... I don't believe I've, uh, heard that song before...
answer: Aintcha gonna innerduce us, Pete?

question: Don't know their names. I seen 'em first!
answer: Ladies, you'll have to pardon my friend here; Pete is dirt-ignorant and unschooled in the social arts. My name on the other hand is Ulysses Everett McGill and you ladies are about the three prettiest water lilies it's ever been my privilege to admire. Why, thank you dear, that's very, uh...

question: Holy Saint Christopher!
answer: Whuhh...

question: Oh sweet Lord, Everett, looka this!
answer: PETE! Where the heck are ya! We ain't got time for your shenanigans!

question: Sweet Jesus, Everett! They left his heart!
answer: What on earth is goin' on here! What's got into you, Delmar!

question: Caintcha see it Everett! Them sigh- reens did this to Pete! They loved him up an' turned him into a horney- toad! Pete! Come back! Don't worry, Pete! It's me, Delmar! Oh Everett! What're we gonna do?!
answer: ...I'm not sure that's Pete.

question: Course it's Pete! Look at 'im! We gotta find some kinda wizard can change 'im back!
answer: ...I'm just not sure that's Pete. You can't display a toad in a fine restaurant like this! Why, the good folks here'd go right off their feed!

question: I just don't think it's right, keepin' him under wraps like we's ashamed of him.
answer: Well if that is Pete I am ashamed of him. The way I see it he got what he deserved - fornicating with some whore a Babylon. These things- -don't happen for no reason, Delmar. Obviously it's some kind of judgment on Pete's character.

question: The two of us was fixing to fornicate!
answer: Heh-heh. You'll have to excuse my rusticated friend here, unaccustomed as he is to city manners. Well mamzel I guess we'll have a couple a steaks and some gratinated potatoes and wash it down with your finest bubbly wine- ...And I don't suppose the chef'd have any nits or grubs in the pantry, or - naw, never mind, just bring me a couple leafs a raw cabbage. How d'you do, Big Dan. I'm Ulysses Everett McGill; this is my associate Delmar O'Donnell. I sense that, like me, you are endowed with the gift of gab.

question: Languishing! Goddamn campaign is languishing! We need a shot inna arm! Hear me, boys? Inna goddamn ARM! Election held tomorra, that sonofabitch Stokes would win it in a walk!
answer: Well he's the reform candidate, Daddy.

question: ...Yeah?
answer: Well people like that reform. Maybe we should get us some.

question: And thank you as well for that conversational hiatus; I generally refrain from speech while engaged in gustation. There are those who attempt both at the same time but I find it course and vulgar. Now where were we?
answer: Makin' money in the Lord's service.

question: You don't say much friend, but when you do it's to the point and I salute you for it.
answer: Oh, it weren't nothin', I-

question: Yes, Bible sales. The trade is not a complicated one; there're but two things to learn. One bein' where to find your wholesaler - word of God in bulk as it were. Two bein' how to reckanize your customer - who're you dealin' with? - an exercise in psychology so to speak. And it is that which I propose to give you a lesson in right now.
answer: I like to think that I'm a pretty astute observer of the human scene.

question: No doubt, brother - I figured as much back there in the restaurant. That's why I invited you out here for this advanced tutorial.
answer: ...What's goin' on, Big Dan? Big Dan, what're you doin'?

question: It's all about money, boys! Atsy answer! Dough re mi! Do unto others before they do unto you! I'll just take your show cards... ...and whatever you got in the hole. What the... It's nothin' but a damn toad!
answer: No... you don't understand...

question: Don't you boys know these things give ya warts?
answer: Oh Lord... Pete...

question: End of lesson. So long, boys! Hee-hee! See ya in the funny papers!
answer: Pete... Pete... Pete...

question: Believe me, Delmar, he would've wanted us to press on. Pete, rest his soul, was one sour-assed sonofabitch and not given to acts of pointless sentimentality.
answer: It just don't seem right, diggin' up that treasure without him.

question: Maybe it's for the best that Pete was squushed. Why, he was barely a sentient bein'. Now, soon as we clean ourselves up, get a little smell'um in our hair, we're just gonna feel a hunnert per cent better about ourselves and about... ...and about... life in general... Jesus. We must be near Parchman Farm. Sorry sonsabitches... Seems like a year ago we bust off the farm... Pete have a brother?
answer: Not that I'm aware.

question: Who the hell is that?! Starla McGill you mean! How come you never told me about her? And that's another thing - why're you tellin' our gals I was hit by a train! Well - I take your point. But it leaves me in a damned awkward position vis-a-vis my progeny. You Waldrip? ...Have you been using my hair treatment? S'cuse me... Well, I got news for you case you hadn't noticed - I wasn't hit by a train. And I've traveled many a weary mile to be back with my wife and six daughters.
answer: That ain't your daddy, Alvinelle. Your daddy was hit by a train.

question: Now Penny, stop that!
answer: No - you stop it! Vernon here's got a job. Vernon's got prospects. He's bona fide! What're you?

question: I'll tell you what I am - I'm the paterfamilias! You can't marry him!
answer: I can and I am and I will - tomorrow! I gotta think about the little Wharvey gals! They look to me for answers! Vernon can s'port 'em and buy 'em lessons on the clarinet! The only good thing you ever did for the gals was get his by that train!

question: ...Why you... lyin,... unconstant... succubus! Oh yeah? Well you can't marry my wife!
answer: He's not my husband. Just a drifter, I guess... Just some no-account drifter...

question: Deceitful! Two-faced! She-Woman! Never trust a female, Delmar! Remember that one simple precept and your time with me will not have been ill spent!
answer: Okay, Everett.

question: Hit by a train! Truth means nothin' to Woman, Delmar. Triumph a the subjective! You ever been with a woman?
answer: Well, uh, I - I gotta get the family farm back before I can start thinkin' about that.

question: Well that's right! If then! Believe me, Delmar, Woman is the most fiendish instrument of torture ever devised to bedevil the days a man!
answer: Everett, I never figured you for a paterfamilias.

question: ...Pete?
answer: They're fixin' a ambush! Do not seek the treasure!

question: ...Pete?
answer: Do not seek the treasure!

question: We thought you was a toad! We thought... you was... a toad!
answer: Do not... seek... the treasure!

question: Them straw polls is ugly.
answer: Stokes is pullin' ah pants down.

question: Gonna pluck us off the tit.
answer: Pappy gonna be sittin' there pants down and Stokes at the table soppin' up the gravy.

question: Latch right on to that tit.
answer: Wipin' little circles with his bread.

question: Suckin' away.
answer: Well, it's a well-run campaign, midget'n broom'n whatnot.

question: Devil his due.
answer: Helluva awgazation.

question: Problem a p'seption.
answer: Ass right.

question: Reason why he's pullin' ah pants down.
answer: Gonna paddle ah little bee-hind.

question: Ain't gonna paddle it; he's gonna kick it real hard.
answer: No, I believe he's a-gonna paddle it.

question: Well now, I don't believe assa property scription.
answer: Well, that's how I characterize it.

question: Well, I believe it's mawva kickin' sichation.
answer: Pullin' ah pants down...

question: We didn't abandon you, Pete, we just thought you was a toad.
answer: No, they never did turn me into a toad.

question: Well that was our mistake then. And then we was beat up by a bible salesman and banished from Woolworth's. I don't know if it's the one branch or all of 'em.
answer: Well I - I ain't had it easy either, boys. Uh, frankly, I - well I spilled my guts about the treasure.

question: Huh?!
answer: Awful sorry I betrayed you fellas; must be my Hogwallop blood.

question: Awful sorry I betrayed you fellas; must be my Hogwallop blood.
answer: Aw, that's all right, Pete.

question: It's awful white of ya to take it like that, Everett. I feel wretched, spoilin' yer play for a million dollars'n point two. It's been eatin' at my guts.
answer: Aw, that's all right.

question: You boys're true friends! You're m'boon companions!
answer: Pete, uh, I don't want ya to beat yourself up about this thing...

question: I cain't help it, but that's a wonderful thing to say!
answer: Well, but Pete... Uh, the fact of the matter is - well, damnit, there ain't no treasure! Fact of the matter - there never was!

question: I never knocked over any armored- car. I was sent up for practicing law without a license.
answer: But...

question: Damnit, I just hadda bust out! My wife wrote me she was gettin' married! I gotta stop it!
answer: ...No treasure... I had two weeks left on my sentence...

question: I couldn't wait two weeks! She's gettin' married tomorra!
answer: ...With my added time for the escape, I don't get out now 'til 1987... I'll be eighty-four years old.

question: Assa good idea, Pappy.
answer: Helluva idea.

question: Cain't beat 'em, join 'em.
answer: Have him join us, run our campaign 'stead a that pencil-neck's.

question: Enticements a power, wealth, settera.
answer: No one says no to Pappy O'Daniel.

question: Oh gracious no. Not with his blandishments.
answer: Powas p'suasion.

question: McGill. No, the marriage'll take place as planned.
answer: Just a little change of cast. Me and the little lady are gonna pick up the pieces'n retie the knot, mixaphorically speakin'. You boys're invited, of course. Hell, you're best men! Already got the rings. Where's your ring, honey?

question: I ain't worn it since our divorce came through. It must still be in the rolltop in the old cabin. Never thought I'd need it; Vernon bought one encrusted with jewels.
answer: Hell, now's the time to buy it off him cheap.

question: We ain't gettin' married with his ring! You said you'd changed!
answer: Aw, honey, our ring is just a old pewter thing -

question: Ain't gonna be no weddin'.
answer: It's just a symbol, honey -

question: End of the road, boys. It's had its twists and turns -
answer: Waitaminute -

question: - but now it deposits you here.
answer: Waitaminute -

question: You have eluded fate - and eluded me - for the last time. Tie their hands, boys.
answer: You can't do this -

question: Didn't know you'd be bringin' a friend. Well, he'll have to wait his turn -
answer: Hang on there -

question: - and share one of your graves.
answer: You can't do this - we just been pardoned! By the Governer himself!
